content: Session 09acecc1-a64c-4b5c-bd16-93a0911da95a transcript
Disorder: GAD
Hi Richard how are you today?

I'm okay, I guess. (Avoids eye contact, adjusts posture) A bit tired, but that's just how it is. Long week at work, you know. (Pauses, glances at the clock) The reports... they take time to finalize. I'm managing, though.
what kind of work do you do?

I work in project management, I guess. It's... it's all about making sure details line up. You know, coordinating teams, ensuring deadlines are met. It can be... it can be demanding, but I just break things down step by step. Helps me stay on top of things. Though sometimes I find myself double-checking reports late at night. (Slight shrug) Just part of the job, I suppose.
why are you at the clinic today?

I guess... work has been stressful lately. (Fidgets with hands) You know, deadlines piling up. I've been having trouble sleeping, even when I'm exhausted. (Pauses, looks at the floor) My doctor suggested I talk to someone about... about staying on top of things. It's not a big deal, really.
what do you think is the problem?

I think... I overthink things, maybe? (Taps fingers lightly on knee) Like, I need to make sure everything's covered, you know? If I don't check the reports three times, what if something slips through? (Forces a small smile) It's just... part of the job, I suppose. Though lately even small tasks take longer. My brain feels like it's running in circles. (Pauses, adjusts tie) But it's not that bad, really. Most people handle worse.
what feeling would you call this?

I guess... it’s like having static in your head. You know, that low hum that’s always there. Maybe like... a fog? I catch myself going over the same report three times, or my hands get this twitch when I’m trying to pour coffee. It’s not a panic attack or anything dramatic. Just... this weight. But I tell myself, ‘Richard, you’ve got systems in place. The 5:30 AM alarm, the checklists—it’s all just part of the job.’ That’s just how it is.
so like panic this is some kind of anxiety?

I guess... if panic is a lightning strike, this is more like a storm that never clears. You feel the static in your bones, you know? Like your muscles are always cranked up half a notch. The twitch in my hands when I'm making coffee—it's not a sudden scare, just... constant. But I tell myself, 'Richard, you’re just thorough. The 5:30 AM alarm? That’s just how it is.'
Does this anxiety ever settle down during the day?

Not really. It’s like... a radio on low in the background. Maybe when I’m raking leaves on weekends, it quiets a little? But even then, I’ll catch myself thinking, ‘Am I doing this right? Should I be doing something else?’ At night, though—it’s worse. My head feels like static, and my hands get that twitch again. I tell myself, ‘Richard, you’re just tired. The 5:30 AM alarm will reset it.’ That’s just how it is.
have you done anything that relieves you of this anxiety?

I guess the wine helps, a little. Two glasses most nights—my wife used to call it my 'nightcap ritual.' It’s not that I get drunk, just... quiet the noise. And the 5:30 AM alarm? Forces me to stay on schedule. If I don’t reset, the static just builds. On weekends, raking leaves or those old NASA docs—maybe the routine itself? Even if my hands still twitch, it’s... structure. But honestly? It’s like mopping a floor while the tap’s running. You’re just resetting the same thing.
Has your wife ever been worried that you rely on the nightcap too much?

She probably thought something like that, yeah. We... had our talks about it before we split. Not that it matters now, since we're not together. I mean, it's just a way to unwind. Two glasses, nothing more. My coworker says I'm the only one who brings a wine opener to staff meetings. Just part of the routine. Not like I'm hiding it or anything.
Are your coworkers concerned about the quality of your work?

I guess there's been... some feedback. Nothing direct, but you pick up on things. Like how they glance at the clock during meetings when I ask the same questions. Or the way the team lead said, 'We need to keep moving forward' after I triple-checked the budget report. I just want to make sure nothing slips through, you know? It's part of the job. Though... sometimes I stay late to recheck my work, and maybe that's what they're really talking about. I try not to let it bother me. I tell myself, if I'm over-preparing, at least it's not the opposite problem.
But isn't that silly to be checking so much?

I guess... it might look that way. But when you've seen mistakes cost projects, you learn to double-check. The team lead's just stressed about deadlines, I think. Honestly, if staying late to recheck things keeps reports clean, isn't that better than rushing? Though... maybe I could trust myself more. That's just how it is, though. My hands still twitch a bit from the coffee I drank, but the wine helps unwind after. Helps me sleep, anyway.
Well, it seems that's just bad to be using alcohol. Do you feel ashamed?

I guess... it's not exactly the healthiest habit. But it's just a glass or two, really. Helps me unwind after the day. My ex used to say I needed to cut back, but everyone's got their little rituals, right? It's not like I'm... you know, drinking myself into a fog. Just enough to quiet the noise in my head. That's just how it is. Though... I suppose if it were really a problem, I'd have heard more about it by now. The main thing is getting some sleep, and the wine helps with that. Even if I still worry I'm relying on it too much.
No man, that sucks. Driking at night is a problem.

I guess... it's not ideal, but it's not like I'm blacking out or anything. Just enough to... quiet the noise. The main thing is getting some sleep, right? I mean, if it were really a problem, wouldn't I have heard more about it by now? My hands still feel twitchy from the coffee, but the wine helps me unwind. Maybe I could switch to decaf or something. Though... if I don't have the wine, I just lie there counting the hours until morning. That's just how it is.
Bullshit man. Why do you do that? No wonder your wife left!

I guess you could say... I'm just trying to get through the day without messing up. The wine isn't some grand failing—it's a way to quiet the static long enough to sleep. As for my wife... she left because I couldn't stop second-guessing every decision, from paint colors to which bills to pay first. You want the truth? I'm more worried about my son's relapse than my own habits, but that's a different conversation. That's just how it is.
Do you ever feel angry?

I guess... I don’t know. Angry feels too strong. Maybe frustrated? Like when I’m going over a report for the third time and my hands start twitching. My coworkers probably think I’m short-tempered, but it’s just... the pressure, you know? I catch myself snapping at the TV sometimes. But it’s not really anger. It’s more like the static never lets up. Even when I’m trying to focus, my head’s full of gears grinding. That wine helps, but it’s just... routine, right?
